text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
on CNBC the Pennsylvania Democratic
primary has already brought us a
surprise in this race the surprises that
it matters at all this is a democratic
primary calendar that was built to be
over in early februari that's what
Hillary Clinton was counting on but it
didn't work out that way and now an
extended race is Hillary Clinton's
friend in the state of Pennsylvania she
could not have a more favorable
demographic environment a lot of older
voters and blue-collar voters white
blue-collar voters who have been very
favorable constituencies for her she's
been pressing hard to try to get an
impressive victory here but of course
Barack Obama who's got a big edge in
financial donations is fighting back
hard trying to keep down her popular
vote margin and any victory in delegates
that she pulls out of here to keep his
status as the front-runner in this race
I want to bring in my New York Times
colleague Jeff Zeleny and talk Jeff
about what makes this race different
from the recent primaries that we've
seen the first thing is we've had six
weeks to campaign it's almost like Iowa
at the beginning of the process it feels
like Iowa although it's a little bit
warmer out but really what's happening
here there are thousands of supporters
campaign strategist volunteers many
people who actually worked in Iowa and
this almost has a bit of a general
election feel to it they have operatives
blanketing this hey it's etc but really
throughout january in February all these
contests were sort of thrown together
the campaign's really have had time to
organize and that could
but be an advantage to Senator Barack
Obama but right now as he said the
demographics favor senator Clinton and
she's counting on that for a win tonight
let's talk about tone and tactics one of
the things that strikes me is different
about this race Barack Obama has been
tougher sharper in going after Hillary
Clinton at the end of the campaign than
is some previous contests why is that
happened the reason senator Obama is
being sharper and you really heard it on
Saturday Sunday and then again on monday
is that he realizes that through some of
the other contests ohio and texas he did
not close as strong as he could have
closed so now he is really saying the
voters have a choice here it's been sort
of confusing for some voters because
he's been talking about Senator McCain
as much as Senator Clinton so in the
final days he wanted to remind voters
that they have a choice in the
Democratic side of this ticket here and
he's really hit her quite hard harder
than he has really in months so we'll
see if that works at the end here
the deeper Jeff that we've gotten into
this campaign the further away we have
gotten from a focus on the war in Iraq
which in the Democratic primary was
helpful to Barack Obama and the more
we're talking about the sagging economy
which we've always thought was going to
be Hillary Clinton's issue because of
her husband's record in the 1990s and
that blue collar support how has that
changed the dynamic of the race well
it's changed the dynamic in a in a
significant way I mean senator Clinton
really has an advantage sure when
talking about the economy but I've
noticed over the last three days I've
been out with Senator Obama at every
stop in every town and he begins his
speech by reading some type of local job
statistic so many people are out of work
because of this plant closed in to that
point closer he's really trying to
connect with voters on the economy but
this still is a big advantage to him but
in the final days in the campaign
senator Clinton still a put-up or
closing ad without safety and security
and and Senator Obama responded with
this ad reminding voters that he did not
vote for the war in Iraq so the economy
is the main issue but it still comes
back a bit to Iraq Jeff you're talking
about connecting with voters one of the
things that we saw early in the campaign
lots of huge rallies for Barack Obama
and some in this state as well but it
also seems that the campaign's trying to
put him in smaller settings more
intimate settings where people can see
him as a candidate close to people and
not somebody who simply as a rock star
drawing big crowds that's right the
movement of Senator Barack Obama has
been really good for his campaign
throughout the year but it's also been a
bit of a detriment his campaign
strategist believe in focus groups in
some people say we're not sure if we're
comfortable with this some movement so

here a little bit now more because

that's really pretty extraordinary
10,000 last night in Pittsburgh but the
image that the campaign wanted voters to

of Senator Obama surrounded by maybe 30
35 people under a blooming dogwood tree
i think it was yesterday and that was
the image state want to have him
surrounded by people because the the
movement thing is a is a negative for

how much does that help given two

universally known and so is able to get

the advertising how much is Barack
benefit by all that he's put on TV it
really raises this pegs for him and it
to raises his expectations here he is
outspent senator Clinton at least to the
one in the end it might probably be more

it's senator Obama Obama Obama
interspersed a bit with Clinton but i
think the financial advantage
more than we can equate here at em en
mainly on the ground game they have so
much going on phone calls door knockers
every undecided voter is supposed to get
a knock on their door twice in the last
48 hours from the Obama campaign the
Clinton campaign does not have the money
to do all these resources so money is a
big thing and going forward if this goes
forward to Indiana and North Carolina
how can senator puttin a raise money and

let me close with this question we're
standing outside the park hyatt hotel
here in Philadelphia where Hillary

is going to be in Indiana tonight why is

senator Clinton if she wins today as she

and move forward she's not as strong in

senator Obama knows he's most likely not

taking that energy with him and he has a

it should be Clinton country he's not
campaign there at all but he is going
down there to appear with a John

regardless of what happens here in a
Pennsylvania
thanks Jeff we're going to be checking

well as the role of blue-collar voters
